III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4150
Section (1) Any incident resulting in serious injury of a resident or illness
Description requiring inpatient hospitalization, shall be reported to the parent/
legal guardian, responsible referring agency, and the licensing
authority as soon as possible, but not more than 24 hours after the
incident.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Facility did not have injuries documented.
Investigation I reviewed intake dated 02/22/2023. It states Youth A previously
being placed at the facility and was admitted to a new placement
on 02/21/2023. Youth A has severe autism and is nonverbal.
Upon placement, Youth A was observed with a two-inch abrasion
to his left shoulder and a ¾ inch cut under the abrasion. He also
has a faint healing bruise and scrape to his lower back, a small
scratch to his buttocks and behind his right knee as well. The
facility was unaware of any incident reports or of injuries to Youth
A.
I observed Youth A at another facility with DHHS Worker and
Complainant on 02/22/2023. Youth has severe autism and is
nonverbal. It is noted that Youth A was placed at the facility being
investigated from 01/04/2023 through 02/21/2023. New
placement Staff Person 4 reports observing scrapes, cuts, and
slight bruising during Youth A’s intake shower at the new
placement on 02/21/2023. Youth A’s left shoulder appeared
irritated with fingernail scratches, as well as a scratch to the left
middle torso, and a cut to his right upper inner leg. Youth A was
observed scratching his arms, legs, and torso throughout the
meeting and vocalizing.
Staff Person 1 was interviewed onsite with DHHS Worker on
03/03/2023. She reports being employed by the facility for three
months and is up to date with her trainings. Staff Person 1 reports
being aware of Youth A having a rash from the time of his
placement and states he went to the doctor for it sometime in
02/2023, indicating he received an ointment. She also reports
Youth A being placed in the hospital at another time as well. She
reports being Youth A’s one-on-one staff the day before he left the
facility and reported to Chief Administrator and Supervisor the
scratch to Youth A’s leg and that he was digging at it. She did not
observe the abrasion to his shoulder. Staff Person 1 states Youth
A had a history of scratching himself when frustrated and did have
temper tantrums where he would throw things and fall to the floor
on his knees and then roll around.
Staff Person 2 was interviewed onsite with DHHS Worker on
03/03/2023. He reports being employed by the facility three
months and is up to date with his trainings. He reports previously
being Youth A’s nighttime one-on-one staff since 01/2023, and
that he assisted in his showers. He notes Youth A enjoyed taking
2

showers at times to include 2:00am, 3:00am, 4:00am, and 5:00am
stating that it would calm him as well as after his diaper was
changed. Staff Person 2 states that Youth A would take off his
clothes and diaper on his own and that he would shower him. He
reports showering Youth A on 02/19 and noticed Youth A
scratching at his left shoulder which was red and believes he oiled
it for him. Staff Person 2 states he did not observe the cut to his
leg or scrapes to his back. Staff Person 2 states he did not see
Youth A scratch at himself because Youth A was sleeping much of
the time he supervised, other than during shower time. He also
states Youth A would throw items when frustrated but did not see
Youth A throw himself to the floor or observe anyone being rough
with him. Staff Person 2 states he does not believe Youth A was
seen specifically by the nurse for the scratching to his shoulder
though notes Youth A went to the doctor at the end of 01/2023 for
an enema.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed onsite with DHHS Worker on
03/03/2023. She reports being employed for less than two
months and is up to date with her trainings. Her 02/19/2023
incident report was read to her, and she states it is accurate. She
reports Staff Person 2 being Youth A’s one-on-one and that Youth
A stripped naked and walked onto the third floor and that she also
walked onto the third floor to assist. She reports Youth A
eventually calmed down and was given a snack and that he again
became aggressive by overturning a mattress and dresser.
Supervisor 2 states she then assumed the role of Youth A’s one-
on-one and states he would not keep his clothes on. She reports
Youth A eventually calmed enough for him to take her hand and
that they walked downstairs to the main floor. Supervisor 2 states
Youth A let go of her hand and ran toward and out the back door
of the facility and into an open field. Supervisor 2 reports running
toward Youth A who was also running through a dip in the field
that contained brush, sticks and rocks. She reports Youth A fell
and that she began to talk to and calm him. She reports Youth A
stood up on his own and that the two walked back into the building
and stayed in the office where he watched tv and ate a snack and
used the staff bathroom shower. After approximately an hour
Youth A was lead back upstairs where he went to bed. Supervisor
2 noted the scratch to Youth A’s leg and reports he has a history
of scratching his back and legs, as well as throwing himself to the
floor during temper tantrums.
Staff Person 3 was interviewed onsite with DHHS Worker on
03/03/2023. He reports being employed for nine months and is up
to date with his trainings. He reports being Youth A’s one-on-one
3

three days a week during the dayshift and that he completed
Youth A’s body chart before being discharged on 02/20/2023.
Staff Person 3 reports previously observing Youth A’s scratch to
his rib area, the shoulder abrasion, and mid-back rash noting that
it was not bruising. He reports not previously observing the leg
scratch until completing the body chart. Staff Person 3 states
Youth A has a history of scratching, noting that the facility thought
it may have been due to the soap and changed it to a mild brand.
Staff Person 3 states he observed Youth A to have outbursts to
include tearing up his bedroom, screaming, stripping down naked,
and scratching at his face. He does not recall ever witnessing
Youth A throw himself to the floor but states he could see Youth A
doing it. Staff Person 3 does not know if the nurse has seen him
for every scratch, but states Youth A has been to the hospital for
his bowels and skin irritation. Staff Person 3 states staff are good
with him and notes that he has heard of him running outside and
that he has a one-on-one as his safety plan. He reports Youth A
enjoys taking frequent showers as his coping skill.
Youth B was interviewed onsite with DHHS Worker on
03/03/2023. He reports knowing Youth A during his placement
and notes that he AWOL’d frequently by walking away from the
group and that staff were required to follow him.
I reviewed the following incident reports:
01/11/2023 incident report notes Youth A scratching his
chest and body due to dryness after showering. It also
notes him hitting his thighs causing redness. Scratches,
redness and a little bleeding were noted to the chest, thighs,
and back of neck and arms. Antibiotic cream applied.
02/19/2023 incident report notes Youth A being given a
shower and changed. Youth A started to run back and forth
and then ran out the back door and was escorted back
inside by Staff Person 2. No injuries noted.
02/19/2023 incident report notes Youth A exiting building to
be escorted back by Staff Person 2. Supervisor 2 then
assumed one-on-one responsibilities and brought Youth A
downstairs. Youth A ran out the back door and into the
alley area and dropped his body to the ground to prevent
being escorted back. Shower given and scratch on leg
noted.
02/20/2023 incident report notes Youth A being showered
4

and was observed to have irritated skin from scratching skin
and bruise to top left shoulder as if he bumped into
something or fallen. Hygiene supply changed as possible
reason for skin irritation. Youth A also self-harms when
frustrated. Bruise to shoulder, scratch marks to back, skin
irritation to backs of both legs, scratch to back, and scratch
under eye noted, and antibiotic ointment applied.
I reviewed the facility’s Critical Incident Response and Reporting
policy. The facility’s policy is to ensure safe, effective, and
transparent response to incidents of a critical nature. Physical
injury (client or to staff by client) is listed.
DHHS Worker did not determine any findings on 03/22/2023.
Analysis There is no evidence to indicate that the facility did not have Youth
A’s injuries documented as they are noted on the 02/19/2023 and
02/20/2023 incident reports. Furthermore, the 01/11/2023 incident
report notes redness and scratches to Youth A’s chest, thighs,
back of neck and arms. Youth A has a history of irritated skin
predominantly on his left shoulder and scratching himself. The
02/19/2023 incident report, where Youth A ran through a dip in the
field that contained brush, sticks and rocks, noted a scratch to his
leg as observed by Supervisor 2 following the incident. The
injuries noted were sufficiently documented and do not rise to the
level of serious injury requiring the notifications stipulated in the
rule.
Technical Given Youth A is nonverbal and unable to explain how he
Assistance received any scrapes, cuts, and bruises, staff are recommended
to diligently examine such youth after all potential incidents in
which harm could have resulted, document, and treat if deemed
necessary. It is further recommended that with such nonverbal
youth, that staff maintain a daily body-chart log to establish a
timeline of injuries or marks not documented during a critical
incident in which an injury is immediately observed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
